posts.cooked:
Per the Digital Markets Act, WhatsApp has to interoperate with other messengers. Signal can now apply to WhatsApp to allow Signal users to send message to WhatsApp users and vice-versa.

Even if we were to reach consensus in this thread (lol), I doubt it will have any real-world effects as Signal itself needs to decide, but I‚Äôm interested in hearing some informed and persuasive opinions.

My perspective is that a big pro of interoperability would be providing an avenue to easily adopt and convert more users to Signal. A big con would be a potential compromise in privacy (e.g. metadata?). Interested to hear what you all think.

Some background reading:

The Verge ‚Äì 6 Sep 24

WhatsApp will send messages to other apps soon ‚Äî here‚Äôs how it will look

You‚Äôll get an option to keep your chats separate.

Android Police ‚Äì 23 Feb 24

Signal and Threema want nothing to do with WhatsApp

The EU is forcing WhatsApp to open up to competitors

link_counts.title: WhatsApp will send messages to other apps soon ‚Äî here‚Äôs how it will look - The Verge

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Anything associated with Facebook is a guaranteed downgrade in privacy

key arguments are already layed down.

if signal becomes interoperable with whatsapp (or telegram), i may seriously drop using signal, or at least it goes into secondary priority.

i simply do not trust meta platforms inc. (similar arguments to some other big tech companies like alphabet inc.)

there was this scandal recently with coxmedia (i hope name is correct.), where they spied users using microphones and facebook was intermediary. whatsapp has mic access, and whatsapp is owned by same parent company. even though that facebook wasn‚Äôt direct spy, these privacy violations start to be scary and creepy.

This calls for a poll.

Signal should become interoperable with Whatsapp
  • Yes
  • No
0 voters

polls.name: poll
polls.title: Signal should become interoperable with Whatsapp

posts.cooked: I love it. Thank you. Although I‚Äôll say I can‚Äôt vote yet. Can you include an ‚Äòundecided‚Äô option? My opinion isn‚Äôt firm enough which is part of the reason I started this thread.

because context is whatsapp (meta inc), my answer is plain no.

however, if the other system would be like matrix protocol, then it is becoming more complicated, and my answer could be maybe. matrix could be a privacy problem, and it is possible that meta inc (or other corporation) is there somehow. but matrix could be also good one and depends heavily on server and its policies. if assuming yes for matrix, users should have clear opt-out, and messages should be marked clearly, if there are from matrix and from what server.

Anything that causes more data to flow in Meta‚Äôs direction would be bad for everybody. So interoperability is no option. Even if Meta would switch to Signal‚Äôs implementation of groups and overall metadata handling, I would find it very hard to trust them regarding the fact that their business model is collecting as much data as possible about people coming in contact with their services and then using it against them.

Would be cool but in practice Signal would loose many of its privacy and security protections to meet Whatsapp interoperability requirements.

That‚Äôs the neat part of the DMA: to facilitate messaging interoperability and break market dominance, small players would need to follow the biggest players, other way is not possible because not much leverage.

I predict zero messaging apps will interoperate with Whatsapp, including Signal.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: Against. Unnecessary operational headaches that would take way too long to get over and leave sour tastes that can be avoided.

Akikou:

My perspective is that a big pro of interoperability would be providing an avenue to easily adopt and convert more users to Signal.

I‚Äôm not sure that would be the case.
If Signal became interoperable with WhatsApp, there is no chance in hell I am converting the few stragglers stuck on WA to Signal - they will tell me ‚Äúoh but now you can receive our messages on your favourite Signal app‚Äù. At least with Signal being independent I could choose to go nuclear and say I am only contactable on it.
Plus, as others have said, metadata protection would have been watered down massively to allow for interoperability, so the argument in favour of more privacy would be seriously weakened.

Akikou:

I love it. Thank you. Although I‚Äôll say I can‚Äôt vote yet. Can you include an ‚Äòundecided‚Äô option? My opinion isn‚Äôt firm enough which is part of the reason I started this thread.

It would clear the current results, so no. While creating the poll I did consider adding a third option, ‚ÄúHELL no‚Äù, though .

My opinion doesn‚Äôt matter, but I‚Äôve been thinking the same thing. Imagining those on the margins, that is, those thinking of installing Signal so they can communicate with someone, why would they do it if in the meantime it happens that they don‚Äôt need to use Signal and can use whatever app is now interoperable with Signal. Also, seems to me, if apps become interoperable, eventually a few, and then fewer, will become dominate, and the rest, over time, will drop out of the market.

I think it‚Äôd be a much easier argument to get someone to just try Signal out because they‚Äôll still be able to communicate with everyone they ‚Äúleft‚Äù on WhatsApp because they won‚Äôt have left them at all.

posts.name: Froiz
posts.cooked:
The outcome of the scenario you describe is Signal trying to offer a better UX than WhatsApp, which isn‚Äôt the goal of Signal. That‚Äôs the game Telegram is playing on Europe by the way, and it‚Äôs winning because it‚Äôs easier to offer a better UX compromising privacy.

What I looking forward for WhatsApp interoperability is an alternative ‚ÄúWhatsApp Client‚Äù to ban Meta software from my phone.

I do hope there will be an application that prevents me from having meta on my own device, but interact with WhatsApp users.

I have tried to convince people to use signal, but for some it is a problem installing an extra app. On the other hand SMS is not a good alternative and have had issues sending them to my native country.

However, I would not want signal to interoperate as I would want them to be clearly separate.

posts.cooked:
I miss some nuance here, also in the poll. If it is possible that Signal has the little data it needs to communicate through its own Signal protocol, and Whatsapp tells us that it uses it to enable interoperability. And in the meantime, Signal ensures that really no metadata is sent to them, or that it is properly randomized/anonymized in advance, then the interoperability with WhatsApp should not be a problem, right? Or am I seeing that wrong?

This would be my dream scenario.

Also I found here the developers site from Meta and the technical documentation of how they planning to make it interoperable:

Meta for Developers

Messaging Interoperability | Meta for Developers

Enable users of your app in Europe to exchange messages with other WhatsApp users in Europe, ensuring compliance with the Digital Markets Act (DMA).

scontent-ams2-1.xx.fbcdn.net

429585070_953768389648649_3452347076893196812_n.pdf

702.57 KB

Also I am wondering how many of you have already read and understand these documents before saying a hard no to interoperability with WhatsApp? Or are these no answers, just a simple no to the company? I‚Äôm just wondering.

Brigitte13e:

And in the meantime, Signal ensures that really no metadata is sent to them, or that it is properly randomized/anonymized in advance, then the interoperability with WhatsApp should not be a problem, right?

This is not possible, Signal needs to send the client IP address and phone number / username, sealed sender wouldn‚Äôt be available.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: If you‚Äôre curious you could make a poll

Brigitte13e:

And in the meantime, Signal ensures that really no metadata is sent to them, or that it is properly randomized/anonymized in advance, then the interoperability with WhatsApp should not be a problem, right? Or am I seeing that wrong?

On the Whatsapp end you would have to have stuff like your profile information so that the person on the other end can tell who you are. Metadata on communication on the Whatsapp end can then easily be collected and correlated with that profile information.
